title: Hays Travel buys up all 555 Thomas Cook shops and takes on staff
text:
Some good news for Thomas Cook staff finally (Picture: PA; Getty)

A buyer has been found for all 555 Thomas Cook stores in the UK.

British travel agent Hays Travel said today it would take over all the stores after the holiday company collapses.

Hays has already recruited 421 former Thomas Cook staff, a statement said.

The company now intends to reopen the shops immediately, potentially saving up to 2,500 further jobs.

It also promised to create another 100 jobs at its Sunderland headquarters.

The independent travel agent’s founders, John and Irene Hays, said: ‘Thomas Cook was a much-loved brand employing talented people. We look forward to working with many of them.

Hays Travel said it would be a ‘gamechanger’ (Picture: PA)

‘The agreement will see Hays Travel acquire a total of 555 stores around the UK, providing re-employment opportunities for a significant number of former employees of Thomas Cook’s retail operations who were made redundant.’

Mr Hays added: ‘It is a game-changer for us, almost trebling the number of shops we have and doubling our workforce – and for the industry, which will get to keep some of its most talented people.’

The government completed the country’s biggest peacetime repatriation on Monday, returning 140,000 UK-based Thomas Cook customers stranded abroad by the company’s bankruptcy.

Thomas Cook folded three weeks ago (Picture: AFP)

In total, around 600,000 customers around the world were left stranded following the collapse of the 178 year-old company less than three weeks ago.

The company’s demise sparked 22,000 job losses worldwide.

The news left around 150,000 passengers stranded abroad, the last of whom were returned to the UK on Monday.

Jim Tucker, a KPMG partner who was appointed joint special manager of Thomas Cook’s retail division after the failure, said: ‘This is an extremely positive outcome, and we are delighted to have secured this agreement.

‘It provides re-employment opportunities for a significant number of former Thomas Cook employees, and secures the future of retail sites up and down the UK high street.’
